Hewlett, Arthur
Gannington Manor
To Sask., May, 1894

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A brief explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in pioneer days will have experienced exactly the same things as anyone else. Some may have had more difficulties than others; some may have been more fortunate than others. It is not necessary to answer every question; those who do not know about leaving blank spaces. The intention is to give detailed answers or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1911, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whatever their age. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did You Do?" and one will be sent to you. Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Instructions for Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office
University of Saskatchewan
Dakota Road
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES - A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. A. Hewlett, Esq.,
Garnington Manor,
Saskatchewan.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences. Some of these questions may not apply to you; others may be more applicable than others. The best way to answer them is to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whatever born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did You Answer This," and will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions

1. Your full name: Arthur Hewlett
2. Your address: 360 Hewlett Avenue, Saskatoon, Canada
3. Date: April 10th, 1982

6. What was your mother's occupation?

8. When did you first come to Western Canada? (You do not need to list every place you lived.)
9. What were your reasons for coming?

When I was about 17 years old, I came to Saskatchewan because my family had moved there and I wanted to join them.

A man by name of Mr. Beaton had come over from England to find work and meet a country girl. He married her and came to this settlement of Saskatoon Manor.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Shared ideas. Some a good thing.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Myself

13. What mode of transportation did you use?

Train out to the West and all on liner and colonist car back to Edmonton to Calgary

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (Describe you part on the trail! Meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other incidents etc.)

After travelling in comfort on the train the colonist car seemed like a prison. An 8-10 mile drive with the mail driver as he had to go a long way round to serve all the settlements. We could see a huge cotton field in the distance and the mail came back loaded with grain.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I had come out to be a homesteader so I knew no one and the mail came back loaded with grain.

16. Where did you settle?

In the town of 1897 city father advanced a lot of money to build a house. We bought a farm for $500.00

17. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Western Canada?

Hewlett Arthur

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

We had a good job to work for a year after that we got my father a farm for 5 years.

By then we became major farmers in the first world war.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Shared ideas. Some a good thing, others like being thrown to the wind.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Myself

13. What mode of transportation did you use?

Steamship Canadian Pacific Line, then overland to Edmonton and colonists carried a knapsack train to Bannings.

14. What incidents of the journey (lost on the journey, accidents in other circumstances, etc.)?

Meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents in other circumstances.

15. How did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I had come out to a Mr. Hardy at Lake Louise, Alberta.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the spring of 1897, only father advanced a farm after moving on for 3 years of started farming.

17. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Western Canada?

None

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

We had a good job to work together for 8 years.

After that came the time to begin planning for the future world war.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Have a brother in Edmonton who was working for the government of Alberta but now lives in Alberta. Another who lived on the farm over 7 for some years since died.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

The big bush fire in the Moore cabin is an outstanding event in my mind. I had barely got to my destination at St. Hubert when the whole settlement was called out to fight the bush fire on the Indian reserve. We fought all one week there. The whole settlement, cutting a place to back fire between lakes and only got back to camp at the reserve buildings very late at night. Then there was a heavy rain on the following afternoon and everyone went to the village and ended up there.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

There was a thriving community in Banffington, church etc so that we did not have to travel far. Means of travel: saddle horse, buggy, buckboard, democrat, etc., ox team.
